Judul: Re : Bls: Re : [neat] ask about=
 NEAT

  
Hi,
Download one of the NEAT implementation (don't ask me which o=
ne is the best, 
it's your choice). Run basic examples, like learning the X=
OR function, a often 
included example of supervised learning. Read the pap=
er that introduce NEAT, not 
all, but at least the section about how it's d=
one, a one hour effort. If you 
data are vector of fixed size, it's very st=
raighfoward to move from the XOR 
example to your problem.

But anyway, if =
the real problem is to actually build a classifier and not 
tinkering with =
NEAT, better first have a good reason to use NEAT and not 
something more s=
imple (Occam razor principle). A perceptron with backprop, you 
got plenty =
of implementations for it in the most esotheric languages, and it's 
easy t=
o do your own if you wish to. Same goes for SVM, if you don't use fancy 
ke=
rnels. And both are likely to be faster for many supervised learning tasks.=
 I 
might be corrected by the others, but I think the original purpose of N=
EAT was 
to do *UNSUPERVISED* learning. Don't expect a less informed algori=
thm to be 
better than a better informed one :p

Alex

Terkirim: Rab, 6 April, 2011 23:01:48=

Judul: Re : [neat] ask about NEAT

 

Hi,

NEAT optimize neural network. N=
EAT will generate many neural network, and you 
give a *fitness* to each ne=
ural network. Higher fitness means more interesting 
neural network.

Thus,=
 with NEAT, you can produce neural networks that can themselves can be used=
 
for doing classification. Your fitness for a given neural network should =
be its 
classification performance. To avoid over-learning (a classifier wh=
ich does not 
generalize), be careful to not use the same sample set to com=
pute classification 
performance.

Also, be sure that more classic machine =
learning methods are not suitable, like 
SVM or back-prop, they are likely =
to be faster if they work good enough on your 
problem. Those methods are l=
ess general than NEAT but can exploit some 
properties specific to supervis=
ed learning for speed gain.

Alex

      <p>Hi,<br>
  Download one of the NEAT implementation (don't ask me=
 which one is the best, it's your choice). Run basic examples, like learnin=
g the XOR function, a often included example of supervised learning. Read t=
he paper that introduce NEAT, not all, but at least the section about how i=
t's done, a one hour effort. If you data are vector of fixed size, it's ver=
y straighfoward to move from the XOR example to your problem.<br>
<br>
But =
anyway, if the real problem is to actually build a classifier and not tinke=
ring with NEAT, better first have a good reason to use NEAT and not somethi=
ng more simple (Occam razor principle). A perceptron with backprop, you got=
 plenty of implementations for it in the most esotheric languages, and it's=
 easy to do your own if you wish to. Same goes for SVM, if you don't use fa=
ncy kernels. And both are likely to be faster for many supervised learning =
tasks. I might be corrected by the others, but I think the original purpose=
 of NEAT was to do *UNSUPERVISED* learning. Don't expect a less informed al=
gorithm to be better than a better informed one :p<br>
<br>
Alex<br>
<br>

Hi,<br>
<br>
NEAT optimize neural network. NEAT will generate ma=
ny neural network, and you give a *fitness* to each neural network. Higher =
fitness means more interesting neural network.<br>
<br>
Thus, with NEAT, yo=
u can produce neural networks that can themselves can be used for doing cla=
ssification. Your fitness for a given neural network should be its classifi=
cation performance. To avoid over-learning (a classifier which does not gen=
eralize), be careful to not use the same sample set to compute classificati=
on performance.<br>
<br>
Also, be sure that more classic machine learning m=
ethods are not suitable, like SVM or back-prop, they are likely to be faste=
r if they work good enough on your problem. Those methods are less general =
than NEAT but can exploit some properties specific to supervised learning f=
or speed gain.<br>
<br>
Alex<br>
